mn21:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn21:2.1: Now at that time, Venerable Phagguna of the Top-Knot was excessively mingling with some nuns.
mn21:2.3: if any bhikkhu criticized those nuns in his presence, Phagguna of the Top-Knot got angry and displeased, and even instigated disciplinary proceedings.
mn21:2.4: And if any bhikkhu criticized Phagguna of the Top-Knot in their presence, those nuns got angry and displeased, and even instigated disciplinary proceedings.
mn21:2.5: That’s how close Phagguna of the Top-Knot was with those nuns.
mn21:3.1: Then a bhikkhu went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was going on.
mn21:4.1: So the Buddha addressed one of the bhikkhus,
mn21:4.2: “Please, bhikkhu, in my name tell the bhikkhu Phagguna of the Top-Knot that
mn21:4.4: “Yes, sir,” that bhikkhu replied. He went to Phagguna of the Top-Knot and said to him,
mn21:4.6: “Yes, friend,” Phagguna replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
mn21:5.1: “Is it really true, Phagguna, that you’ve been excessively mingling with some nuns?
mn21:5.3: if any bhikkhu criticizes those nuns in your presence, you get angry and displeased, and even instigate disciplinary proceedings?
mn21:5.4: And if any bhikkhu criticizes you in those nuns’ presence, they get angry and displeased, and even instigate disciplinary proceedings?
mn21:5.5: Is that how close you’ve become with those nuns?”
mn21:5.7: “Phagguna, are you not a gentleman who has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness?”
mn21:6.1: “As such, it’s not appropriate for you to be excessively mingling with nuns.
mn21:6.2: So if anyone criticizes those nuns in your presence, you should give up any worldly desires and thoughts.
mn21:6.3: Even in that case, you should train like this:
mn21:6.4: ‘My mind will be unaffected, and I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain compassionate for [the criticizer's] welfare with a mind of friendliness and no inner hate.’
mn21:6.6: So even if someone strikes those nuns with fists, stones, rods, and swords in your presence, you should give up any worldly desires and thoughts.
mn21:6.7: Even in that case, you should train like this:
mn21:6.8: ‘My mind will be unaffected, and I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain compassionate for [the attacker’s] welfare with a mind of friendliness and no inner hate.’
mn21:6.10: So if anyone criticizes you in your presence, you should give up any worldly desires and thoughts.
mn21:6.11: Even in that case, you should train like this: ‘My mind will be unaffected, and I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain compassionate for [the criticizer's] welfare, with a mind of friendliness and no inner hate.’
mn21:6.13: So Phagguna, even if someone strikes you with fists, stones, rods, and swords, you should give up any worldly desires and thoughts.
mn21:6.14: Even in that case, you should train like this: ‘My mind will be unaffected, and I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain compassionate for [the attacker's] welfare, with a mind of friendliness and no inner hate.’
mn21:7.1: Then the Buddha said to the bhikkhus:
mn21:7.2: “Bhikkhus, I used to be pleased with the bhikkhus.
mn21:7.4: ‘I eat my food in one sitting per day.
mn21:7.5: Doing so, I find that I’m healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
mn21:7.6: You too should eat your food in one sitting per day.
mn21:7.7: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.’
mn21:7.8: I didn’t have to keep on instructing those bhikkhus;
mn21:7.9: I just had to prompt their recollection.
mn21:7.10: Suppose a chariot stood harnessed to thoroughbreds at a level crossroads, with a goad ready.
mn21:7.11: Then a skilled horse trainer, a master charioteer, might mount the chariot, taking the reins in his right hand and goad in the left. He’d drive out and back wherever he wishes, whenever he wishes.
mn21:7.12: In the same way, I didn’t have to keep on instructing those bhikkhus;
mn21:7.13: I just had to prompt their recollection.
mn21:7.14: So, bhikkhus, you too should give up what’s detrimental and devote yourselves to beneficial qualities.
mn21:7.15: In this way you’ll achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.
mn21:8.1: Suppose that not far from a town or village there was a large grove of sal trees
mn21:8.2: that was choked with castor-oil weeds.
mn21:8.3: Then along comes a person who wants to help protect and nurture that grove.
mn21:8.4: They’d cut down the crooked sal saplings that were robbing the sap, and throw them out. They’d clean up the interior of the grove,
mn21:8.5: and properly care for the straight, well-formed sal saplings.
mn21:8.6: In this way, in due course, that sal grove would grow, increase, and mature.
mn21:8.7: In the same way, bhikkhus, you too should give up what’s detrimental and devote yourselves to beneficial qualities.
mn21:8.8: In this way you’ll achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.
mn21:9.1: Once upon a time, bhikkhus, right here in Sāvatthī there was a housewife named Vedehikā.
mn21:9.3: ‘The housewife Vedehikā is gentle, even-tempered, and calm.’
mn21:9.4: Now, Vedehikā had a bonded maid named Kāḷī who was skilled, tireless, and well-organized in her work.
mn21:9.6: ‘My mistress has a good reputation as being
mn21:9.8: But does she actually have anger in her and just not show it? Or does she have no anger?
mn21:9.9: Or is it just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside?
mn21:9.10: Why don’t I test my mistress?’
mn21:9.11: So Kāḷī got up during the day.
mn21:9.15: ‘You’re getting up in the day—what’s up with you, wench?’
mn21:9.17: ‘Oh, so nothing’s up, you naughty maid, but you get up in the day!’ Angry and displeased, she scowled.
mn21:9.19: ‘My mistress actually has anger in her and just doesn’t show it; it’s not that she has no anger.
mn21:9.20: It’s just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside.
mn21:9.21: Why don’t I test my mistress further?’
mn21:9.22: So Kāḷī got up later in the day.
mn21:9.26: ‘You’re getting up later in the day—what’s up with you, wench?’
mn21:9.28: ‘Oh, so nothing’s up, you naughty maid, but you get up later in the day!’ Angry and displeased, she blurted out words of displeasure.
mn21:9.30: ‘My mistress actually has anger in her and just doesn’t show it; it’s not that she has no anger.
mn21:9.31: It’s just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside.
mn21:9.32: Why don’t I test my mistress further?’
mn21:9.33: So Kāḷī got up even later in the day.
mn21:9.37: ‘You’re getting up even later in the day—what’s up with you, wench?’
mn21:9.39: ‘Oh, so nothing’s up, you naughty maid, but you get up even later in the day!’ Angry and displeased, she grabbed a bolt-pin and hit Kāḷī on the head, cracking it open.
mn21:9.40: Then Kāḷī, with blood pouring from her cracked skull, denounced her mistress to the neighbors,
mn21:9.41: ‘See, ladies, what the gentle one did!
mn21:9.42: See what the even-tempered one did! See what the calm one did!
mn21:9.43: How on earth can she grab a bolt-pin and hit her only maid on the head, cracking it open, just for getting up late?’
mn21:9.44: Then after some time the housewife Vedehikā got this bad reputation:
mn21:9.45: ‘The housewife Vedehikā is fierce, ill-tempered, and not calm.’
mn21:10.1: In the same way, a bhikkhu may be the gentlest of the gentle, the most even-tempered of the even-tempered, the calmest of the calm, so long as they aren't touched by disagreeable speech.
mn21:10.2: But it’s when they are touched by disagreeable speech that you’ll know whether they’re gentle, even-tempered, and calm.
mn21:10.3: I don’t say that a bhikkhu is easy to admonish if he makes himself easy to admonish only for the sake of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
mn21:10.5: Because when he doesn’t get robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, he’s no longer easy to admonish.
mn21:10.6: But when a bhikkhu is easy to admonish purely because he honors, respects, reveres, worships, and venerates the Dhamma, then I say that he’s easy to admonish.
mn21:10.7: So, bhikkhus, you should train yourselves: ‘We will be easy to admonish purely because we honor, respect, revere, worship, and venerate the Dhamma.’
mn21:11.1: Bhikkhus, there are these five modes of speech with which others might address you:
mn21:11.6: from a mind of friendliness or with inner hate.
mn21:11.7: When others address you, they may do so in a timely or untimely manner,
mn21:11.8: in a factual or false manner,
mn21:11.9: in a gentle or harsh manner,
mn21:11.10: in a beneficial or unbeneficial manner,
mn21:11.11: and from a mind of friendliness or with inner hate.
mn21:11.12: Even in that case, you should train like this:
mn21:11.13: ‘Our minds will remain unaffected, and we will blurt out no bad words. We will remain compassionate for [the other person's] welfare, with a mind of friendliness and no inner hate.
mn21:11.14: We will abide having pervaded that person with a mind of friendliness. And with them as a basis, we will abide having pervaded the whole world with a mind of friendliness—abundant, expansive, immeasurable, free of enmity and ill will.’
mn21:12.1: Suppose a person was to come along carrying a spade and basket
mn21:12.3: ‘I shall make this great earth be without earth!’
mn21:12.4: And they’d dig all over, scatter all over, spit all over, and urinate all over, saying,
mn21:12.7: Could that person make this great earth be without earth?”
mn21:12.10: Because this great earth is deep and immeasurable.
mn21:12.11: It’s not easy to make it be without earth.
mn21:12.12: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

mn21:14.1: Suppose a person was to come along with dye such as red lac, turmeric, indigo, or rose madder,
mn21:14.3: ‘I shall draw pictures in space, making pictures appear there.’
mn21:14.5: Could that person draw pictures in space?”
mn21:14.8: Because space has no form or appearance.
mn21:14.9: It’s not easy to draw pictures there.
mn21:14.10: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

mn21:16.5: Could that person burn and scorch the river Ganges with a blazing grass torch?”
mn21:16.8: Because the river Ganges is deep and immeasurable.

mn21:18.1: Suppose there was a catskin bag that was rubbed, well-rubbed, very well-rubbed, soft, silky, rid of rustling and crackling.
mn21:18.2: Then a person comes along carrying a stick or a stone,
mn21:18.4: ‘I shall make this soft catskin bag rustle and crackle with this stick or stone.’
mn21:18.6: Could that person make that soft catskin bag rustle and crackle with that stick or stone?”
mn21:18.9: Because that catskin bag is rubbed, well-rubbed, very well-rubbed, soft, silky, rid of rustling and crackling.
mn21:18.10: It’s not easy to make it rustle or crackle with a stick or stone.
mn21:18.11: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

mn21:20.1: Even if low-down bandits were to sever them limb from limb with a two-handled saw, whoever corrupts their mind on that account would not be following my instructions.
mn21:20.2: Even in that case, you should train like this:
mn21:20.3: ‘Our minds will remain unaffected, and we will blurt out no bad words. We will remain compassionate for [the other person's] welfare, with a mind of friendliness and no inner hate.
mn21:20.4: We will abide having pervaded that person with a mind of friendliness. And with them as a basis, we will abide having pervaded the whole world with a mind of friendliness—abundant, expansive, immeasurable, free of enmity and ill will.’
mn21:21.1: If you frequently apply your mind to this advice on the simile of the saw,
mn21:21.2: do you see any manner of speech, subtle or coarse, that you could not bear?”
mn21:21.4: “So, bhikkhus, you should frequently apply your mind to this advice on the simile of the saw.
mn21:21.5: This will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.”
mn21:21.6: That is what the Buddha said.
mn21:21.7: Pleased, the bhikkhus delighted in what the Buddha said.
